awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Sequential Predictors for Partial Differential Equation and Delay Systems: Designs, Theory, and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
This project solves the problem of implementability of feedback controls for a variety of dynamical systems that arise in additive manufacturing, battery modeling, deep mine elevators, oil drilling, traffic congestion, water desalination, and other engineering domains. Feedback control involves the use of information about the states of dynamical systems and about their surroundings, to decide how to adjust the behavior of the systems to realize important objectives such as ensuring that the systems safely converge to a desirable operating mode with minimal human intervention. The project combines the PIs' complementary expertise in engineering and mathematics, by tackling important interdisciplinary problems that could not be solved outside of this new collaborative framework. The project studies interconnected systems with delays, in which the current states of the systems or of their surroundings may not be available for use in the feedback control design, and related problems in extremum seeking under delays, in which one wishes to minimize important types of cost criteria. Through the PIs' contacts with engineers from industry, the project will increase the engineering community's use of more rigorous methods to obtain better performing controls and will also provide interdisciplinary training to graduate students that is guided by compelling engineering applications.

The project provides transformative control and extremum seeking algorithms for key classes of ODE and ODE-PDE cascades that involve delays, prescribed regulation times, and uncertainties. Input delays arise from sensor or transport phenomena, and finite time constraints occur when there are hard deadlines for achieving control objectives. While prediction has been used extensively, there are currently no analogs of prediction for stabilization problems with prescribed regulation times where there are delays and uncertain model parameters. This project overcomes these challenges for general classes of nonlinear systems, using new sequential predictors, sequential anti-diffusors, chain observers, adaptive control with parameter identification, and extremum seeking under delays or time constraints, including cases where only sampled output measurements are available. The controls developed ensure better disturbance rejection and robustness against uncertainties. The project is guided by cutting edge engineering applications, to ensure the usefulness of the theory. They involve models for underwater marine robots where slow acoustic communication is modeled through long delays, the reduction of severe slugging in oil production, and online social networks where opinion spreading is modeled by PDE-ODE cascades with diffusion. The project will include experimental real time implementation of some of the controls and train PhD students.

por.por_cntn:
This project developed mathematical techniques for classes of mathematical models that are useful for modeling controlled biological or engineering processes such as the guiding of a semi-autonomous vehicle to follow a desired path. The mathematical models are called control systems, because they contain forcing functions called controls that are chosen by the user to influence the future behavior of the process that is represented by the model. The project primarily studied feedback control problems, where the controls depend on measurements from the system that is being controlled. This included cases where only sampled measurements were available for use in the feedback control, e.g., periodic measurements of components of the state, instead of continuous measurements. A main focus was delayed control systems, where the controls were derived using sequential predictors. Delays in control systems are useful for modeling delayed impacts of changes in control values, such as time lags between the times a thrust is applied to a marine robot and the times that the vehicle responds with a desired motion. Sequential predictors can be helpful for overcoming the challenges of earlier predictor-based delay compensation methods for control systems, by replacing the usual distributed terms that are found in standard predictor-based delay compensating controls by chains of extensions of the controlled dynamics that each contain an unperturbed copy of the original system running on a different time scale.

The research included sequential predictors for classes of bilinear systems arising in the power electronics underlying renewable energy systems. Other applications in the project covered underwater marine vehicles of the type that can be used to search for the effects of pollution. Secondary focuses of the project included (i) the development of finite time control methods to provide control solutions for cases with prescribed deadlines for meeting control objectives and (ii) extremum seeking problems, where a minimum or maximum value of a function must be found without having complete knowledge of the function that needs to be minimized or maximized. By developing mathematical methods that solved significant problems within these three focus areas which were then published in leading applied mathematics and control engineering journals and reported in talks by the PI's research group in seminars and major control and mathematics conference presentations, the project advanced the research frontier at the interface of applied mathematics and engineering and broadly disseminated the findings to the systems and control research community.  Products from the project included 25 journal articles and 3 invention disclosures, one of which produced a patent that was granted in 2020.

In addition to applications related to renewable energy systems and marine robotics that can contribute to understanding the effects of, or reducing, pollution, the broader impacts of the project provided educational opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, who participated as research assistants on the project and in summer Research Experiences for Undergraduates (or REUs), leading to multiple jointly authored papers by the PI and the students. The REUs were sponsored by two supplements to the original award. This provided educational opportunities at the interface of applied mathematics and engineering that would not otherwise have been available in standard single-discipline curricula, and that can better prepare the students for a wide variety of careers that require interdisciplinary interactions.
